title: International cooperation on Road Transport leading to improved mobility, safety, security and prosperity

author: Michael Nielsen, International Road Transport Union

segmentation: Thank you so much, honest.
Yes, I am basically heading the RU office in Brussels so I did that for for roughly four months now, which is very interesting thing.
I was at vertical before.
I'm happy to see some of the old colleagues in the room here.
Good to see that you want to see what the old guys going around doing now.
When Patrick he called me and asked for a presentation from RU on International Corporation.
I was thinking, what should we actually?
What should we talk about here?
Andy, are you?
Is is a global organization representing the professional Rd transport operators.
Around the globe and I thought, well, we have to come up with some kind of of slogan for this presentation.
So thinking globally acting locally, I think that would probably be good.

Cause I mean we are seeing and you will see that through my presentation that there is a globalization going on heavy globalization, but we cannot have let's say avoid to take in consideration the local situations in every country that we basically cooperate with.
Anyway, let me just.
Give you a few ideas of what is the DRU we were created in 1948 with the eight founding members.
We are today 180 members from 70 three countries.

I'm happy to see some of the other speakers from South Africa and Senegal because you will see, let's let's say the African region is is not so populated here and that's something that we think should actually be be done.
So that's.
Good to see.
Maybe we should have a talk about that later on.
We have basically Members, the National Association, representing to transport operators of public transport and goods transportation, Rd transport only.
It's also we have a number of associated members, which is those that building vehicles or offering services or offering technology or offering.
The black gold that we are running on on the trucks and on the buses.
So these are associated to the are you so around 800?
HEA members what is it that we think Rd transport is?
Well we see Rd Transport as a production tool.
We see that as a vital production tool in a global economy.
We don't see Rd transport as a standalone.
We see Rd transport integrated into logistic chain.
We see it integrated into supply chain.
We see it integrated as a production tool because they are running just in time deliveries.
Now if I have to get a shipment of 10,000 of these things.
To Brussels today.
I wanted that tomorrow because I will not get paid before they have my goods.
So we are part of that, so we will have to act on that.
So what we try to do here is to say what does it actually take and nobody knows that.
What does it take in a cafe here in Ljubljana to have a Cup of coffee?
It takes active.
The combined efforts of 29 companies in 18 countries.
Not only for the coffee, the cops, the everything else, the spoon, the sugar, whatever you put in in combined efforts of 29 companies in 18 countries.
That's a lot of people that ask to work together and transport is vital part of that.
Our supplier Volvo vehicle manufacturer has 10,000 suppliers to build a truck.
That's a lot of suppliers.
Each of these suppliers have suppliers, so there is a huge demand, so we have to find out how we can tag.
Older.
By the way, we also know, of course that most of the production is going on in China today, so there's a huge demand there as well.
75% of the products that are sold in Walmart.
Are produced in China.
Interesting observation I think.
So we think that global trade calls for Global Corporation research as well.
We think it's important that we, as well as the International Rd Transport Union.
We have professional transport us at participating in there are giving input to that, ensuring that that gives, let's say the right framework to work iponan to build the future upon.
We think one way of doing it is to exchange best practice.
Between the various regions and.
What I will talk about here today is how can we actually maximize the opportunities here?
How can we do that?
Let's see if I get forward here.
Interlinking businesses we see I mean we heard about Simba Simba once in Batu's in Patrician, before whoever knows how many simplest there will be.
But that's a great thing.
Linking Europe to China, linking Europe to India, linking Europe to Brazil, Argentina, whatever.
But there is other opportunities as well.
If we look a little bit about the transport patterns.
Here we see that a lot of goods.
From the production region, which is, I wonder if I can get this thing to work.
We said mainly here.
Partly here in the East, so here is a huge production reason.
So how is that going by containers today?
Container start about instead in 71.
Basically it actually started a bit earlier in the US when there was a guy that had to pay a lot of tax to get his his goods shipped up to New York and he said, oh that's a bit stupid.
I have to pay that tax across in all these states, so why don't I just take?
I put it in a box and take it by sea to them.
That was the birth of the containers.
So how is it actually going here?
Well, it's very few.
Reports it's focused in.
As you see, 2000, we're here.
Huge concentration here.
Huge concentration up in in Rotterdam, Hamburg.
And huge concentration here on the West Coast.
And that's 2006.
So what is this meaning?
That means basically that you have a huge saturation here, here, here and partly here in Dubai.
Somebody figured out it's a good idea to build.
A big
Thing in Dubai and that's that succeeded.
So what are we saying?
Let me just give one back.
What are we saying?
Where do we have issues actually with?
No developments with the problems with.
Maybe not enough activities which leads to various disturbances in the normal order.
In a lot of these countries that are along here than on land link countries.
So we had a vision some time ago to try to look at how can we actually interlink the Eurasian landmass.
And in that, by doing so, providing prosperity and opportunities for these landlocked countries.
We know that China is a big production company, so already now there's 10s of thousands of trucks that are moving in from China towards Europe.
And we say how can we actually look at that?
Can we actually make that more efficient?
Can we make a opportunity for these countries along that route and then provide, let's say prosperity opportunities for them and we think that yes, first of all we think we can do it.
We have shown it in some cases.
We also think there is a huge opportunity to exchange best practices.
With these countries.
So what are we?
What are we actually said?
It's looking at?
We're looking at the saturated ports, so we're looking at using these opportunities to provide land transport to the Middle East to the CIS region, into the EU.
And by the way, remember that the West Coast here were very saturated as well, so maybe we can just.

Put some sea transport here from towards the East Coast, which is not saturated, because basically this is a huge problem as well for them because they have to move the goods from one side to the other side because the consumption is here.
Thinking globally but acting locally so.
What are we saying?
We are saying we should.
Reopen that Silk Road.
We should look at what can we do in that Silk Road?
How can we work together with the Commission with the research teams, transport DG, whatever?
In order to make sure that all these countries, cities, whatever along these routes here, can have the same possibility as those that actually have a port.
So we actually a couple of times did what we say is Carolines just to prove it can be done.
Because when you have a vision like this, everybody says that's impossible can't be done, no roads.
That can't be true, so we started the caravan.
We drove it from Beijing to Brussels.
And it could be done.
We stopped and along the way we handed out information material.
We had events.
We had everything that basically said OK, that is that is a good thing to do.
We did it in cooperation with the various associations we have in these countries so they have their local perspective on it acting locally but thinking.
Globally.
So what we think now is basically why don't we try to launch a second caravan?
But not to prove that it can be done, because it can be done terrorist infrastructure to do it.
Yeah, it has to be improved here and there.
It has to be improved in European there as well, by the way.
So we say maybe we should do it with a slightly different name now.
And what should that aim be?
Well, the are you and a lot of other people, including you in this in this room here has done a lot to achieve sustainable development Europe.
But what does sustainable develop in Europe actually mean?
If you don't have sustainable development globally?
Very little.
I mean, we're small dot on the global map, so we should never forget that.
So we said why in the world do we not take these trucks here?
And instead of having them filled with the.
With various.
Good is that we can give out during the road.
Why not fill them as displace Whynott show?
What we have done in Europe, where we have done in the state where we have done in other regions.
Two improve Rd safety two improve the security to increase the efficiency to create Harmony Station of rules because it's impossible to drive.
A truck or for that take a train across a lot of photos.
If you have to stop all the time and have have other rules.
I mean, it's bad enough that we drive on the other side in some countries.
At least that has to be respected.
Training.
Give them training.
Can we facilitate free movements?
We have what we call a border waiting time system at Gru that we developed.
Simply cause.
We experienced that there is tremendous problems on the borders.
Entering the EU.
So we said OK, let's try to get a daily update on where the problem lies and identify the bottlenecks and then change some of these procedures or educate the border control officials.
Could we imagine that we do such as a system?
For Europe as well.
Find out how the flow of traffic runs.
Find out for instance.
Longer East how we can ensure that they have the same conditions as we have?
Intelligent transportation systems.
I'm sure we have heard a lot about this these days here.
Tell them what could be done there.
Open up business opportunities along that route.
Open up the possibility when China is saturated.
When China has no more production capacity, open up that weekend.
Production capacity from these regions.
Tell them how to do that.
Educate them on how to do that in and.
Stainable manner.

So what we basically would like to see and we would like to invite all of you to come with ideas and maybe work with us, including of course the European Commission of how in the world can we launch such a campaign?
Could be done through a caravan, could be done through other means as well.
And create, let's say what we call a true and operational International Corporation and not just an international Corporation where you have a couple of meetings and discuss.
Missions or or perspectives, or what potentially could be done, but really have a exchange of best practices.
Show them how it can be done.
Show them in real life.
By having a truck, or by having whatever you want to show them.
That this is the way we can do it, and I think that would lead to an improved mobility, safety, security and more importantly, prosperity.
Because if you cannot buy your daily bread, you don't give.
I nearly said this shit for the rest.
You don't care about.
Let's say maybe you care about security, but you don't care about mobility.
Good mobility if you don't eat.
So you have to create prosperity before you can get the other things and prosperity you can maybe get by.
Let's say linking these landlocked countries.
To where the market is and where the knowledge is, which is in high extent in Europe.
So that's what we would like to do.
We would like to invite you to do that 'cause we can do this on a global basis.
We can improve it on a global basis, but we can more importantly improve it on a local basis.
In all these countries.
We are discussing this at our World Congress in Istanbul, which is taking place in a couple of weeks.
This is the theme after World Congress peace and prosperity in these regions.
Funny enough, these regions so unfortunately most instable regions as well.
There's a reason for that.
And we will try to live up to our slogan which is working together for a better future.
So let's try to do that.
Let's try to realize this, and we aim at that link starting some of this up in in 2009.
So, and we are heavily thinking about it now, so I invite you to discuss it with me too.
Send me whatever information you might have or whatever you would like to do, or however you would like to participate where there for them.
There is no limitation of how many vehicles we can have in that caravan on what type of vehicles we can happen that caravan.
So thank you very much.
That's my message for today.
